Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Existence pour le SNU d’un plan post Matthew incluant des initiatives concrètes et un plan de mobilisation de ressources pour le financement du plan et pour la coordination des différents secteurs OUI/NON
2. Existence au bureau de pays d’un mécanisme de coordination pour le relèvement précoce post Matthew et d’un programme articulé dans le Plan du SNU incluant des projets de relèvement précoces et priorisant les groupes vulnérables (femmes, enfants, personnes agrées…) OUI/NON

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

1. Existence et efficacité d’une stratégie et d’un plan de mobilisation de ressources ainsi que n mécanisme de gestion et de suivi du pipeline et des rapports aux bailleurs (YES NO);
2. Existence d’outils et de mécanismes spécifiques au Bureau d’Haïti pour synthétiser les informations de gestion à l’intention du management(YES NO)
Dans quelle mesure le projet appuie le programme en vue d’améliorer l’efficacité et la qualité du travail
De manière inadéquate Très partiellement Partiellement Largement
Existence et efficacité de mécanismes ou de plateformes permettant la communication des résultats du Programme au public YES NO

comment.narrative: 1. Au lendemain du tremblement de terre de 2010, le PNUD-Haïti dispose d’un draft de stratégie de mobilisation de ressources, les rapports aux bailleurs sont gérés de manière ad hoc. Il n’y a pas de mécanisme de suivi du pipeline. Alors que, le nombre de bailleurs a triplé et les exigences en matière de reporting ont suivi la même tendance. 2.Il n’existe pas d’outils et de mécanismes pour synthétiser des informations de gestion à l’intention du Management 3.Dans le contexte post-tremblement de terre et avec un afflux et un turnover important de personnel et Besoin d’appui du des collègues en vue d’améliorer l’efficacité et la qualité du travail 4. Il n’existe qu’une seule plateforme pour la communication avec le public

1. OUI, L’utilisation efficace de la stratégie de mobilisation de ressources et le maintien des mécanismes de gestion et de suivi du pipeline et des rapports aux bailleurs sont assurés. 2. OUI. Le maintien et l’amélioration d’outils et de mécanismes spécifiques au Bureau d’Haïti pour synthétiser les informations de gestion à l’intention du management sont assurés. 3. Le projet appuie partiellement le programme en vue d’améliorer l’efficacité et la qualité du travail 4. OUI, Le maintien et l’amélioration de mécanimes et de plateformes efficaces permettant la communication des résultats du Programme au public sont assurés

1. OUI, L’utilisation efficace de la stratégie de mobilisation de ressources et le maintien des mécanismes de gestion et de suivi du pipeline et des rapports aux bailleurs sont assurés. (Des ateliers de travails ont été organisé par unité de programme du bureau du pays afin de peaufiner les approches thématiques et d’identifier des domaines de synergies avec des bailleurs tels que l’Union Européenne et le Canada. Le suivi et communication sur les rapports aux bailleurs, ainsi que le pipeline ont été maintenus. Des outils plus automatisés pour ce suivi sont en considération. 46 MM$ ont été mobilisés durant l’année (25 MM$ étant pour les élections).
2. OUI, les outils et mécanismes de suivi du Programme au bureau d’Haiti ont été maintenus et continuent à être améliorés pour synthétiser les informations de gestion à l’intention du management. (On peut noter entre autre les outils permettant le suivi financier (tableaux et graphes) ; le suivi des documents programmatiques et administratifs; le suivi de la mise en œuvre des recommandations des Audits etc…)
3. Le projet a pu appuyer partiellement le Programme en vue d’améliorer l’efficacité et la qualité du travail. (Les documents de projet, les plans de travail et les rapports ont été révisés. Un appui conseil sur les procédures et l’utilisation des instruments corporatifs a été fourni. Une assistance ponctuelle a été fournie pour la gestion des évaluations. Des séances de formation ont été organisées sur les procédures du PAC, des ateliers de travail pour faciliter l’alignement du programme et la mise en œuvre de l’assurance qualité ont été organisés. L’ICF a été révisé et 15 micro-évaluations ont été finalisées permettant d’avancer la mise en œuvre de HACT).
4. OUI, Le maintien et l’amélioration de mécanismes et de plateformes efficaces permettant la communication des résultats du Programme au public sont assurés. (102 articles et reportages produits par différents médias sur les initiatives du bureau. 24 ar

1. OUI, L’utilisation efficace de la stratégie de mobilisation de ressources et le maintien des mécanismes de gestion et de suivi du pipeline et des rapports aux bailleurs sont assurés. 2. OUI. Le maintien et l’amélioration d’outils et de mécanismes spécifiques au Bureau d’Haïti pour synthétiser les informations de gestion à l’intention du management sont assurés. 3. description.narrative: Establishing a Financially Sustainable National Protected Areas System in Haiti.

title.narrative: GEF - Mid-term evaluation: Establishing a financially sustainable National Protected Areas System

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Etablissement d'un Système National d'Aires Protrégées (SNAP) GEF PIMS4150 BD FSP:HTI PA FIN
Energy - policy, planning and administration
By June 2014 Haiti has designed and started initial implementation of an integrated operational and financial framework to ensure long term sustainability of the national PA system

Area in hectares in the protected areas and number of APs legally included in
SNAP

comment.narrative: There are 10 PA in Haiti covering a total surface of 12854 ha But none of them are legally incorporated to the NPAS which is not officially implemented to date
At the End of Project at least the 3 major PA are legally incorporated into the NPAS covering 10500 ha ie 86 of surfaces covered by PA in Haiti

An important effort was made by the SNAP
i 3 Priority Protected Areas Macaya Park Park 8166 ha La visite Park 11426 ha Citadelle Park 2500 ha Foret des Pins Unit I Park 14000 ha and Foret des Pins Unit II Park 4780 ha are legally incorporated in NPAS they constitute the bulk of the SNAP with an area of over 22 000 has They were extended through presidential decrees in 2013
ii The study on the representativeness of Ecosystems SNAP is underway and the final document is scheduled for August 30 2015
iii The continued demarcation activity at the tour with support from CIAT
iv The Macaya management plan is realized and ready to be submitted for validation
v The SNAP project works with the ANAP the CNIGS and CIAT for the delineation of other protected areas in the country to reach the international standard Meanwhile final study on AP representativeness and consistency was undertaken
bays Park 75618 ha National Natural Parc IleàVache 11235 ha Grosse Cayes Protected area management Habitat Species Aquin wet area 10974 ha OlivierZanglais Protected area management Habitat Species 7553 ha Fonds des Cayes Protected area management Habitat Species 2365 ha Pointe Abacou Protected area management Habitat Species 1840 ha PortSalut Protected Natural Landscape Marine and Terrestrial 1840 ha Marie Jeanne Cave 31ha Plaine Cahouane Protected area management Habitat Species et associated
watershed 5940 ha
vi Besides the study emphasis is made in the delineation of some of these protected areas Currently the ANAP is currently working on demarcation boundary marking of these legally defined Pas The Citadelle Park was created by CIAT and pursuing now working on the boundary demarcation of the Macaya PA including La Visite Park with the support of the SNAP project

A SNAP financial strategy with required tools to mobilize and use efficiently the resources in the longterm financing process was developed and finalized by four international consultants on four themes i funding strategy assessment of options for financing PA at national level and at one or two iconic PA ii the financial Needs Assessment and establishment of a financial management system iii Economic valuation of ecosystems and ecosystem services for payments PES and iv sustainable tourism component The main outputs produced are
Review of the current financial situation of Haitis PA national system and
national agency and the current accounting system of the National System of Protected Areas SNAP
Financial Plan of the National System of Protected Areas SNAP and the National Agency for Protected Areas ANAP
Tools on Financing of Protected Areas of Haiti
calculation of Payments for hydrological services provided by protected areas in Haiti
Methodology guideline for economic valuation of protected areas of Haiti
Economic Evaluation of priority protected areas Haiti
Financial tool on sustainable tourism
Solutions for official endorsement and implementation of these strategies are being identified However at date no remarkable progress has been noticed so far
The SNAP project is working towards achievement of this outcome However it will be very difficult to measure the progress made in term of financial sustainability of PA
Network due to the fact UNDPs financial score card is not well adapted to newly established PA network like in Haitis one
Further action is initiated with ANAP to ensure appropriation and ownership of the financial strategy by ANAP and partners

description.narrative: Rate of importance of the performance and management activities at the level of SNAP measured by the intermediary METT

comment.narrative: Level of METT reference for the 3 protected areas was Low 1 Foríªt des Pins 33 Macaya 32 La Visite 32 less thaan 45 Low
By end of Project METT scores for the 3 PA of reference will have moved to the medium METT category 4554 Medium

The financial strategy SNAP has been finalized and various innovative tools for
mobilizing financial resources to ensure longterm financing of SNAP have been
Identified and developed
The capacities of National Agency of Protected Areas to manage SNAP have been further reinforced by GEFUNDP project and other partners in the management of established protected areas Important effort was also made on the recruitment and training of parks directors and technical park maintenance officers surveillance staff including elaboration of management plans in priority protected areas
A methodological guideline for the development and management of PA planning
Has been achieved The training modules are followed by the other partners working in Forêt des Pins and Trou Caiman a new protected area currently being created It is Planned to start the construction works of three other parks management plan for 3 Baies La Visite and Foret des Pins The process of developing management plans is closely coordinated by the ANAP and involves the participation of local actors living in
park areas
SNAP project has recruited consultants for the development of these plans The management plan of Macaya Park is elaborated in cooperation with the ANAP CIAT UNDP UNEP and the IDB The management plan of La Visite will be conducted jointly with the ANAP CIAT the Seguin Foundation and UNDP The management plan of the Foret des Pins is done in cooperation with ANAP CIAT UNDP and Helvetas Swiss Cooperation
In collaboration with IADB and the governmental Technical Unit Baseline studies
are conducted for socioeconomic and biological data collection essential to the achievement of the Management Plan of the Parks The achievement of management plans of the protected areas allows programming in time and space for activities within and around the protected area However there is a need to further empower ANAP for ownership development and application of these tools developed

description.narrative: Improved PA governance system backed by policies regulations and competent institutions enables more cost efficient use of funds available for PA management

1 Degree of adoptionenforcement of a National PA System Policy which 1 defines the NPAS and the ANAP 2 clarifies the roles and responsibilities of the Ministries of Environment and Agriculture and their dependencies 3 involves local governments and actors

comment.narrative:
Currently there is no official definition of the NPAS and the ANAP is neither defined nor implemented
The legal and institutional frameworks are not enforced

By year 2 a NPAS policy has been prepared
By Year 3 the policy is approved
By Year 4 the policy is in force

The SNAP project has supported the design and capacity building of ANAP as a legally effective Governmental agency to cope the management of increasing number of protected areas A set of strategic documents involving policy legal frameworks Organic law regulations and guidelines were developed and will be submitted officially to the Government for endorsement and legal approval for SNAP governing management and operation nationwide However there are still some barriers hat need to be lifted by ANAP such as i low or poor fund raising ii
Demarcation of PAs boundaries mapping description etc iii enforcement of regulations access to resources and sanctions etc iv lack of well trained professional and surveillance teams for established PAs v lack of social and economic alternatives for a growing population living in and around PAs
A 5 years Business Plan was developed and finalized as part of the development of the financial strategy The project worked in synergy support PARC project to provide efficient support to MoE in the development of its organic law which is an essential prerequisite for ANAP reinforcement
The promotion of the Organic Law and the strategy organizing the management and sustainable financing mechanisms planned is not yet conducted as the proposed Law framework is not yet adopted
The finalization of the website planned for this year is not yet developed is will being developed and will be likely operational before end of the project As for the Webmaster its creation will start in October 2015
The elaboration and implementation of database on Pas and Biodiversity is on good progress and will be finalized by August 2015

Comanagement agreements have been identified as valuable tools for financing the
countrys protected areas as
Middle to reduce costs supported by the State
Mechanism of PA management in collaboration with NGOs local associations
or private sector such as Park Martissant comanaged by FOKAL a national Haitian NGO under a contract However there is no sharing of information on management costs The comanagement councils for Foret des Pins planned for this year is not yet operational due to the lack of designed management plan
ANAP has organized meetings with its technical and financial partners to explore
and consider the use of the tools in some parks where partners are already active
as Macaya and La Visite including 3 Bays marine park

Renforcement des capacit\xE9s face au changement climatique

description.narrative: Renforcement des capacités adaptatives des communautés côtières d’Haïti aux changements climatiques
independent political entity

1) Number of ministries which integrates climate risks into planning processes nor implement CC-adaptation related activities 2) Percentage of investment into climate proof the water sector in the southern departments and relevant adaptation technology in targeted areas. 3) Number of institutions partner taking into account gender in the achievement of low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives

comment.narrative: 1) None of the current existing ministry integrates climate risks into planning processes nor implements Climate Change-adaptation related activities. 2) Very Low percentage of investment into climate proof the water sector in the southern region. 3) None of the institutions partner takes into account gender in the achievement of low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives

1) Six Ministries integrate climate risks into planning processes or implement Climate Change adaptation related activities. 2) 50 % of amount of investment into climate proof the water sector in the southern departments and relevant adaptation technology in targeted areas. 3)Three institutions partner taking into account gender in the achievement of low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives

1) Six Ministries integrate climate risks into planning processes or implement Climate Change adaptation related activities. 2) 50 % of amount of investment into climate proof the water sector in the southern departments and relevant adaptation technology in targeted areas. 3) Three institutions partner taking into account gender in the achievement of low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives

1) 6 Ministries integrate climate risks into planning processes or implement Climate Change adaptation related activities. 2) 50 % of amount of investment into climate proof the water sector in the southern departments and relevant adaptation technology in targeted areas. 3) 3 institutions partner taking into account gender in the achievement of low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives

1) 6 Ministries (Finance, Tourism, Planning, Agriculture, Environment, Public Works) integrate climate risks into planning processes or implement Climate Change adaptation related activities. 2) 50 % of amount of investment into climate proof the water sector in the southern departments and relevant adaptation technology in targeted areas with DINEPA and MDE. 3) 3 institutions partner ( DINEPA, MDE, UN-WOMEN) taking into account gender in the achievement of low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives

description.narrative: To strengthen adaptive capacities of populations and productive sectors in coastal areas to address increasing climate change risks
Number of existing department to integrate climate change risks into departmental plans

comment.narrative: None of the current existing departments integrate climate risks into planning processes
Increase in current number by 100

10 departments through the Ministry of Environment and the ministry of Interior as new partner have done the exercise on climate change adaptation integration into local development planning More in depth application training will be held at the end of September 2015

description.narrative: Number of related ministries municipalities CBOs and research institutions implementing climate change adaptation activities

comment.narrative: None of the current set of ministries municipalities CBOs and research institutions implement ccadaptation related activities
Increase the current number by 50 over established baseline at the beginning of the project

More in depth analysis of adaptation measures are being done with ministry of agriculture to be integrated in the farming plan strategy
The ministry of tourism has taken into account the climate change threats in the development of a tourism project in the Southern region
The ministry of Environment has prepared a draft planning document to facilitate the work initiated with the Ministry of Education related to the integration of CC basic knowledge in the Curricula See attached document
DINEPA CNSA ONEV CNIGS Private University the Ministry of Finance the Civil Protection Direction The Civil Society the State University and 15 municipalities continue to implement CC adaptation related activities

description.narrative: Climate Risks Management is fully mainstreamed into humanitarian and development investment frameworks
2 Percentage of humanitarian and development organizations with adaptation targets and budget lines

comment.narrative: None of the national policy and investment frameworks post disaster recovery plan national plans for poverty reduction etc include adaptation to CC targets

2 60 of the donor organizations operating in Haiti have included adaptation to CC in coastal areas as a priority of their investment
3 100 of the national development policies and plans have budget allocated to address clear adaptation to CC targets in coastal areas

Exchange meetings with FAO on their review of the National Adaptation Plan Action in order to share the project best practices on the field
Working with MPCE for ACC integration as a priority in their planning in collaboration with the project AP3CEU and the CC Division
Ongoing discussion with the current director of climate change on the importance of developing the National Climate Change Policy

description.narrative: Percentage of national investment frameworks incorporating adaptation to climate risks

comment.narrative: Some NGOs are starting to incorporate CC adaptation within donor financed investment plans
1 50 of the programmes funded through the interim commission for the reconstruction of Haiti include adaptation to CC targets and clear budget allocations

1 Report on CC Adaptation costs in collaboration with the Finances Ministry is scheduled for presentation to the public by August 20th
2 Ongoing successful exchange meetings are being held with ministry of Tourism and IADB regarding an important Ecotourism project in the Southern region for which the experiences and achievement of the adaptation project are being considered for replication

description.narrative: Institutional capacity to plan for and respond to increasing coastal hazards improved
1 Allocation of budget for CC adaptation targets in sectoral plans Ministries CIAT SNGRD CNSA MARNDR

comment.narrative: None
1 CIAT MDE MPCE MARNDR SNGRD CNIGS DINEPA ONEV CNSA all allocate budget lines to clearly defined adaptation targets

Working with the direction of CC and all other sectorial ministries and relevant actors in the elaboration of the Intended National Determined Contribution A Workshop on INDC elaboration methodologies has been organized for sectorial ministries staff in Port au prince with support from Organisation de la Francophonie
Also the technical and financial support to the direction of climate change has been reinforced through the EUAP3C programme and the inkind contribution of the ministry of environment which is equivalent to 35k
The report on COUNTRY CLIMATE PROFILE intl Consultant has been finalized and will be presented to the public at a workshop on August 20th

Technical trainings on Websmater and communication on climate change have been organized for the ministry of environment Staff and now the website on Climate change is being managed by the Ministry updates and adds
South South cooperation Training sessions were organized in Costa Rica with CATIE for MDE MARNDR staff on
Gender and Climate Change Mangroves restoration Watershed management

description.narrative: Percentage of vulnerable communes with published emergency evacuation plans adjusted to take into account increased climate risks

20 communes with EWS adapted to increased climate risks and communal development plans with CC adaptation criteria

Follow up on the workshop held in march Specific workshop to be held with the representatives of the communes already working on integrating ACC in the communal development plan
An additional workshop will be held in Desdunes Artibonite with the local stakeholders and authorities on July 282930 to work on integrating adaptation to CC measures into their local development planning
Study done on Strategic Environmental Assessment vulnerability assessment regarding the management of inert solid waste in the coastal sites from the earthquake in collaboration with Relevement projectUNDP and MTPTC

description.narrative: Models of best practices and lessons learned from the project activities captured and institutionalized
1 Number of lessons learned systematized about managing climate change risks in coastal areas

comment.narrative: 1 There is very little available information on the adaptive capacities of populations and productive sectors in coastal areas the baseline will be determined at the inception phase
1 existence of knowledge forums and networks on adaptation to CC by the end of the project

The climate change training kit is translated into Creole and available at central level via DEPREDD and at local level in 9 departments via the MDE local offices
Experiences in the Southern region shared via ALM and CCAF plateforms and the CC website
The TORs are finalized for a consultancy on lessons learned and best practices report to be launched by end of 2015

description.narrative: 2 Number of men and women public and decision makers having access to best practices and lessons learned from project activities

comment.narrative: 2 Gender related data are currently not available The baseline will be determined at the inception phase

The consultancy on Gender analysis and gender strategy is ongoing
Documentation on gender is translated into Creole Cf attached documents Training on gender with the local partners is planned during the consultancy

description.narrative: 3 Number of lessons learned disseminated through the ALM platform and other regional networks

comment.narrative: 3 The baseline will be determined at the inception phase

3 By the end of the project project lessons are distributed in hard copy eg pamphlets briefing notes newsletters booklets etc electronically eg via the project database and via national and local workshops
All the materials are disseminated in hard copy CC training manual 4 pamphlets educational banner 4 newsletters success stories photostories and soft copy on ALM and the CC website

description.narrative: Resilience of lowelevation coastal zones to emerging climate change threats enhanced
2 of technologies for water agriculture and food security sectors transferred to targeted areas

comment.narrative: 2 No information available on the effect of CC on the water sector in coastal areas and no mitigation plans available
2 Investments needs identified to climate proof the water sector in the southern departments and relevant adaptation technology in targeted areas installed

CNIGS is working with ONEV on the installation of 3 additional hydro climatic stations and further progress with SNREMARNDR to establish a climatic observation network for the Southern Department This initiative is in collaboration with the project Hydromet of PPCRCIATSNREMARNDR
An important partnership is ongoing with Small Grant Programm on the Mangroves programme with a CBA approach Village planet is providing training to technicians in the ministry of environment to improve their capacities in mangroves reforestation
TOR for a manual capitalizing on the good practices related to water resources and food security management techniques tested in the project is ready for publication
Climate Change Awareness programme are ongoing in the project sites

description.narrative: increase in awareness and response capacity to climate change and its impacts particularly on the water and agriculture sectors by the communities in pilot areas

comment.narrative: 1 Current field programs efforts remain largely dispersed with very little consideration paid to the new patterns of risk brought about by climate variability and change
1 100 increase in the outreach and sensitization activities in all the communes in the pilot areas

Ongoing preparation of a guidelines for replication and upscaling of good practices from the pilot project in the South East drinking water distribution systems management
Second phase of water storage and distribution project with DINEPA to enhance capacities for economic valuation of the investment and maintenance of the water distribution system 3 CAEPA will be reinforced during a 6 months time frame

description.narrative: Strengthening of capacities to address climate risk and food security within coastal rural livelihood y strategies in targeted areas indicated by of people engaged in resilient livelihood activities

comment.narrative: 3 No information available on the effect of CC on rural livelihoods in vulnerable watersheds and no mitigation plans available
3 Investment needs identified to climate proof rural livelihoods in targeted vulnerable watersheds and efficient monitoring system in place to guide adapted transfer of technology in targeted areas

In the Southern region the project is working with 5 more watershed committees to elaborate the Mangroves management plan
Thanks to resources provided by the project the MARNDR is working with 15 groups of farmers on womens ownership of livestock and other incomegenerating activities There will also be construction of water storage postharvest storage and food transformation facilities as climate change adaptation strategies

description.narrative: Dans quelle mesure l’appui technique et opérationnel est fourni au CEP pour assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral notamment la disponibilité de matériels sensibles et non-sensibles, la publication de la liste électorale 30 jours avant le jour de vote, l’exécution de la liste de paie, la disponibilité des résultats électoraux au CTV, l’exécution de la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

comment.narrative: Besoin du renforcement de la structure organisationnelle du CEP pour assurer le bon déroulement des opérations électorales.

De manière plus que satisfaisante, l’appui technique et opérationnel sont fourni au CEP pour assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral selon le calendrier électoral grâce à la disponibilité de matériels sensibles et non-sensibles ; l’impression et vulgarisation de la liste électorale, l’exécution du paiement du personnel électorale temporaire, la disponibilité des résultats préliminaires, la mise en œuvre de la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

De manière plus que satisfaisante, l’appui technique et opérationnel sont fourni au CEP qui a pu assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral selon le calendrier électoral y compris le premier tour des législatives du 9 aout 2015 et le premier tour des présidentielles, des élections législatives partielles et des élections municipales du 25 octobre 2015. Cela a été assuré grâce à la disponibilité de matériels sensibles et non-sensibles, l’impression et la publication de la liste électorale, l’exécution du paiement du personnel électorale temporaire, la disponibilité des résultats électoraux au CTV, la mise en œuvre de la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

De manière plus que satisfaisante, l’appui technique et opérationnel sont fourni au CEP pour assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral selon le calendrier électoral grâce a la disponibilité des matériels sensibles et non sensibles, l’impression et vulgarisation de la liste électorale, la formation et l’exécution du paiement du personnel électorale temporaire, la disponibilité des résultats préliminaires, la mise en œuvre de la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

De manière plus que satisfaisante, l’appui technique et opérationnel sont fourni au CEP qui a pu assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral selon le calendrier électoral fixé après le passage de l’ouragan Matthew, grâce à la disposition des matériels sensibles et non sensibles, l'’impression et vulgarisation de la liste électorale, la formation et l’exécution du paiement du personnel électorale temporaire, la disponibilité des résultats préliminaires, l'assistance techique a la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

1. Taux de diminution du nombre de personnes se trouvant en situation d’insécurité alimentaire
2. Taux d'augmentation de la population ayant accès aux intrants leur permettant d'accéder à la ration alimentaire minimale établie par la FAO

comment.narrative:
1. Le nombre de ménages se trouvant en insécurité alimentaire est estimé à 38%, soit près de 4 millions de personnes et la prévalence de l’insécurité alimentaire est estimée à 41,7% en milieu rural, contre 33,4% dans la ville de Port-au-Prince et 29,3% dans les autres zones urbaines traduisant une vulnérabilité sociale des populations rurales et urbaines (Enquête de la CNSA 2014).
2. La moitié de la population n’a pas accès à la ration alimentaire minimale établie par la FAO (225 kg d’équivalent céréales/an/habitant).

1. Diminution de 5% du nombre de personnes se trouvant en situation d’insécurité alimentaire à travers 40,000 ménages qui bénéficient d'un accompagnement pour l’autoproduction agricole biologique.
2. Augmentation de 5% de la population ayant accès à la ration alimentaire minimale établie par la FAO soient 40,000 ménages bénéficiant des intrants leur permettant d’accéder à la ration alimentaire minimale établie.

comment.narrative:

1) Les arrangements de gestion et de collaboration sont clarifiés en concertation avec les acteurs stratégiques, 2) L’équipe administrative du projet est recrutée, 3) L’essentiel des arrangements et facilités logistiques sont mis en place, 4) Le comité national de pilotage du projet est constitué, 5) Des mécanismes de concertation au niveau des régions sont initiés avec l’implication de toutes les parties prenantes selon une approche inclusive et représentative ;

Le Prodoc a été approuvé en octobre 2015, les cibles de 2015 sont reportées au 2016. L'atelier de lancement du projet a été réalisé le 24 mai 2016. En conclusion en 2015, on n’a pas eu d’actions concrètes car la mise en œuvre du projet EBA n’a pas été enclenchée comme prévue.

description.narrative: Développement de 3 propositions de projet a soumettre au Fonds Vert pour le Climat pour financement sur demande d'appui technique du gouvernement.
Un portefeuille de projets axés sur la résilience climatique est développé avec le gouvernement d’Haiti et soumis au Fonds vert pour financement.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
